title: For Foreign House Hunters in London, the Time to Act is Now
text:
As the saying goes, one person’s loss is another’s gain—an apt expression for the crippled London housing market, where certain foreign buyers can add a discount north of 30% if they’ve got the right currency in their pockets.



The U.K.’s long-delayed and ever-more-tumultuous uncoupling from the European Union has steadily opened a window to affluent outsiders looking to invest in London. The past year of political wrangling over Brexit has plunged the British pound to its weakest value in a generation and dealt another blow to London’s already depressed real estate market.



At the moment, Americans, as well as Saudis and Emiratis, two Arab nations with currencies pegged to the U.S. dollar, enjoy the steepest discounts in London compared to the last market peak in 2014, according to an analysis by Mansion Global and Dow Jones market data analysts, which looked at currency fluctuations for a dozen major players in the London market.



More: Amid Political Changes, Buyers Would Be Wise to Consider Prime Central London

American buyers in the U.K. are paying roughly one-third less than they were five years ago thanks to favorable shifts in the exchange rate. The benefit, of course, isn’t limited to Americans, per se, but any buyer with U.S. dollars to burn, including any U.K. expatriate getting paid in greenbacks.



This isn’t news to the droves of such buyers who’ve already descended on the London property market, according to Edward Heaton, founder and managing partner of buying agents Heaton & Partners.



“There is evidence of a definite pickup in activity in prime central London at the moment, predominantly from international buyers, who are very open that they believe the combination of a weak sterling and low prices make this the perfect time to buy,” Mr. Heaton said. “Their view is that post-Brexit, regardless of the outcome, that both prices and sterling will pick up.”



Prices in some pockets of central London have fallen as much as 20% to 30% off their 2014-15 peak, which when coupled with the weak sterling “has created the opportune moment for foreign buyers to purchase property at pretty much half the price compared to five or six years ago,” Mr. Heaton added.



“These buyers are taking the view that regardless of the type of Brexit we have, the world is not going to come to an end; London will still be a place to park money,” he said.



More: Forget Perfectly Timing the Market and Focus on What You Can Do Instead

Looking at it another way, in 2014, a U.S. buyer with a budget of US$1 million could maybe cover the cost of a 500-square-foot studio in St. John’s Wood—a popular London neighborhood for American expats in London, according to Mansion Global’s calculation using average price-per-square-foot data from firm LonRes. These days, that exact same budget will, on average, cover 700 square feet due to a stronger dollar and a dip in neighborhood home prices.

Other Currencies Also Benefit

No U.S. dollars? No problem. A strong Hong Kong dollar is also handing residents a major discount on U.K. property at a critical time for residents of the semi-autonomous Chinese city. A favorable exchange rate gives the U.K. housing market particular appeal, as violent clashes between political protestors and police spur affluent Hong Kongers to seek safe havens abroad, Mansion Global has reported.



The Hong Kong dollar now stretches 34% further than it did at the height of the London market in 2014, according to our analysis.



More: For a Safer Bet in a Tough Luxury Market, Consider the Penthouse

Simon Deen, director of London-based property agency Aston Chase, said the firm was involved in five deals involving buyers from Hong Kong since the beginning of September, including a £10.75 million sale at the Corinthia Hotel’s private residences in Westminster.



“Despite the short-term issues with Brexit, they still see London as a good solid base to invest their capital, and also a place to live and educate their children,” said Mr. Deen.



Meanwhile, the buyers from Switzerland, another major player in the London housing market, are seeing a 27% discount on the exchange rate compared to five years ago, followed by Singaporeans with a 22% discount.



Many agents and market analysts have credited an influx of foreign buyers—cognizant of the investment opportunity in London—with driving high-end deals in recent months. A number of these buyers have shown a particular interest in new developments, which has attracted the likes of billionaire American hedge funder Ken Griffin. He’s reportedly agreed to buy a £100 million penthouse at the still under-construction Peninsula Hotel in Belgravia.



“When it comes to the super-rich, if something fits the bill, they’ll buy it,” regardless of stamp duty or Brexit, said Gary Hersham, founder of Beauchamp Estates.



Betting that things could get any better for certain foreign buyers is unwise, he added.

“You can never trade at the bottom and you can never trade at the top, so it’s not prudent to wait,” Mr. Hersham said.



More: Rising Rents, Wary Buyers Means Now Might Be the Time to Buy an Investment Property

Some Remain on the Sidelines

So why might foreign buyers sit on the sidelines despite the dramatic currency discounts?



For one, not every currency has strengthened against the pound. The Australian dollar, for example, has not strengthened against the pound like other major currencies over the past five years. And Russian buyers—once an incredibly important driver of ultra-prime home sales in London—have seen their spending power plummet about 24% since 2014, according to our analysis.



Besides that, there are two main reasons would-be buyers with the means in London have until now opted not to act, agents say.



The first is a desire for more political clarity surrounding Brexit, which as of now has a deadline of Oct. 31. Domestic buyers, as well as foreign buyers that need to sell in order to buy, could make a case for holding off if clarity helps bolster home sales and prices.



But the uncertainty is exactly what’s working in foriegn buyers’ favor at the moment. The pound is expected to strengthen with greater political and economic clarity, particularly if a trade deal is struck, and would thereby chip away at the exchange rate advantage first-time U.S. or EU buyers, for example, now enjoy.



The second bet some would-be overseas investors are making is that Prime Minister Boris Johnson will follow through on vague promises to reform property transfer taxes, known as stamp duty. That includes the possibility of slapping the seller rather than the buyer with the tax bill.



In 2014, lawmakers implemented a graduated stamp duty tax with a top rate of 12% on the price of a home over £1.5 million, and then added another 3% for all second-home purchases two years later.

But those successive stamp duty hikes have already weighed on the housing market to the point that sellers have largely swallowed the added cost through deflated home prices, said Peter Wetherell, chief executive of Wetherell, a Mayfair-based estate agency.



In effect, Mr. Wetherell said in an email, “we already have a tax on the vendors because the values of property have been affected by the stamp duty and land tax.”



But dreams of stamp duty reform are likely just that, as lawmakers will be hesitant to deprive the government’s general fund of the additional revenue enjoyed since the tax was raised in 2014. There’s little-to-no chance Mr. Johnson’s administration will get around to minor policy reforms like stamp duty until Brexit is well behind us.

And if the case for investing now wasn’t already strong enough, international buyers who choose to finance their home purchase can borrow at record-low rates, as Chris Sykes, a mortgage consultant for lender Private Finance, recently noted.

“While home-movers might be tempted to maintain their ‘wait and see’ approach in the face of this political uncertainty,” Mr. Sykes wrote in market commentary, “they should also recognize that this uncertainty is also presenting value and opportunity across the housing market, which isn’t guaranteed to be sustained in the long-term.”
